articles.title: Letter to Kim Jong Il from Barack Obama
articles.content:
Letter to Kim Jong Il from Barack Obama
Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- General Secretary Kim Jong Il received a personal letter from Barack Obama, President of the United States of America.
					 The letter was conveyed to Kang Sok Ju, first vice-minister of Foreign Affairs of the DPRK, on December 9 by Stephen Bosworth, U.S. special representative for DPRK policy who visited the DPRK.

articles.title: Kim Jong Il Puts Wreath on Bier of Kim Kun Ok
articles.content:
Kim Jong Il Puts Wreath on Bier of Kim Kun Ok
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- General Secretary Kim Jong Il sent a wreath to the bier of Kim Kun Ok, a general officer of the Korean People's Army and a lecturer of the Victorious Fatherland Liberation War Museum, on Friday, expressing deep condolences over his death.

articles.title: Kim Yong Nam Congratulates Romanian President
articles.content:
Kim Yong Nam Congratulates Romanian President
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, Friday sent a congratulatory message to Traian Basescu upon his reelection as Romanian President.
					Kim in the message wished the President success in his responsible work for the stability and development of the country.

articles.title: New History Books Published
articles.content:
New History Books Published
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- The Social Science Book Publishing House of the DPRK has brought out new books.
					 The book "Tracing History of Our Ancient Ancestors" contains historical contents about ancestors in the Neolithic era who figured in history from the dawn of human history. 
					
					 The book "History of Japanese Imperialists' Plunder of Korean Cultural Properties" clarifies the truth of the crimes committed by the Japanese imperialists by destroying cultural relics in Korea and fully exposes the Japanese invaders' plunder of cultural properties during the Imjin Patriotic War (1592-1598).
					
					 Also included in the new books are "Stories of Famous Humorists in Middle Ages" and "Folk Tales Told in Korea".

articles.title: Revolutionary Self-reliant Spirit of Kangson Carried Forward
articles.content:
Revolutionary Self-reliant Spirit of Kangson Carried Forward 
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- The workers of the Chollima Steel Complex, in the 100-day campaign, are giving a full display to the revolutionary spirit of self-reliance which had been prevailed in Kangson in the period of the post-war rehabilitation and construction.
					 They have remarkably increased the steel output by making a UHP electric arc furnace with their own efforts and technologies and introducing a Korean-style iron production method.
					
					 During the three-year-long Fatherland Liberation War, the Kangson Steel Plant, the predecessor of the complex, was damaged severely. 
					
					 Seen hither and thither in the compound of the plant were much more than ten thousands of bomb craters, naked steel-frame structures, broken tubes, entangled electric wires and overgrown weeds.
					
					 The workers of the plant, however, turned out in the reconstruction of the plant with the belief that the Korean people could emerge victorious in the post-war rehabilitation and construction under the leadership of President Kim Il Sung as they did in the war. 
					
					 When visiting the plant in August of Juche 42 (1953), the President inspired the workers to boost the steel production, saying that the plant should be reconstructed with local-made equipment and domestic materials and technologies at an early date and that, with a firm conviction, could they do it.
					
					 After his visit they had a meeting to organize a shock brigade and start the restoration of electric furnaces.
					
					 They turned out the first molten iron from electric furnace No. 2 which they reconstructed by themselves in only 40 days following the end of the war.
					
					 Their revolutionary spirit of self-sustenance has been successfully carried forward by the workers in all parts of the country including Kangson to work new miracles and innovations day by day.

articles.title: Forced Name Change, Japanese Policy of Obliterating Korean Nation
articles.content:
Forced Name Change, Japanese Policy of Obliterating Korean Nation
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- The Japanese imperialists forced Koreans to change their first and second names to Japanese ones during their colonial rule over Korea (1905-1945). It was part of their policy of despiritualizing and obliterating the Korean nation.
					 After legalizing the name change in November 1939, they mobilized provincial, county and sub-county offices, police stations and all other ruling tools and pro-Japanese organizations to this end.
					
					 When they faced Koreans' refusal to accept the gangster-like demand, the occupiers coerced their obedience by force of arms.
					
					 They also imposed wicked sanctions in a despicable way upon those who refused to change their names.
					
					 The Japanese imperialists did not allow them to get a job, persecuting them as "unpatriotic person" and "disturbing element" and putting them first on the list of "labor draft" or "patriotic corps", and their children to study at schools of all levels.
					
					 They also abused even the means of transportation in name change, keeping freight of those with Korean names from being transported. 
					
					 Furthermore, they themselves changed the names of Koreans without their knowing.
					
					 Owing to their vicious policy of name change, many Koreans were subjected to national humiliation and pain and even killed.
					
					 The Korean people will surely make Japan to pay for their past crimes.

articles.title: S. Korean Authorities' Unpopular Policy Censured
articles.content:
S. Korean Authorities' Unpopular Policy Censured
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- The Headquarters of Joint Struggle for Democracy and People's Right to Existence which groups more than 260 political parties and civic and public organizations of south Korea held a press conference in Seoul on Dec. 14 at which it denounced the puppet authorities for their unpopular policy.
					 Speakers at the press conference charged that the moves of the authorities to stamp out the labor movement have reached an extreme phase as evidenced by the disciplinary actions taken by them against members of trade unions including the Government Employees' Union and the Teachers Union, their measures to force them to close their offices and cancellation of collective contracts.
					
					 Declaring that all the unions under the Confederation of Trade Unions were ready to call a general strike any time, they warned that people from all walks of life in south Korea would launch a powerful struggle in protest against the authorities' attempt to railroad "bills" against the labor movement, people's living and peace through the "National Assembly".
					
					 Then, they demanded the authorities meet 10-point demands such as a halt to the crackdown upon the trade unions, the repeal of the evil law on media, the settlement of the tragedy in Ryongsan.
					
					 At the end of the press conference members of the said headquarters entered into a sit-in strike in tents in Youido Park, Seoul.
					
					 On the same day the chairpersons of the above-mentioned teachers' union and government employees' union held a press conference in Seoul to protest against the authorities' suppression of the labor movement.
					
					 They declared that they would inform the world of the unreasonable labor policy pursued by the present authorities through solidarity with the international body and wage a struggle to get various kinds of regulations suppressing the labor movement repealed.

articles.title: Probe into Mass Killings of Civilians Demanded in S. Korea
articles.content:
Probe into Mass Killings of Civilians Demanded in S. Korea
 Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- Bereaved families of civilians killed in the past held a "joint memorial service" in Seoul on Dec. 14 at which they demanded a thorough probe into the truth behind the mass killings of civilians.
					 The participants referred to the fact that the Committee for Settling the Past History for Truth and Reconciliation is expected to wind up its work before long though the truth about the mass killings of civilians by U.S. troops, troops of the puppet army and policemen before and after the war has not yet been completely probed. 
					
					 Then, the probe into the mass killings of civilians will come to an end and there will be no organization to which the bereaved families can appeal, they deplored, stressing the need to continue receiving reports about mass killings and conducting the probe into them. 
					
					 They held that the authorities should not dissolve the above-said committee but opt for instituting a law or revising the existing one to ensure that its term is extended.
					
					 They, at the same time, urged the authorities to institute a special law on unearthing all the places presumed to be burial grounds, provide facilities for burying the unearthed remains and reinstate the victims.

articles.title: DPRK Significant Day Observed
articles.content:
DPRK Significant Day Observed
Pyongyang, December 18 (KCNA) -- A meeting was held in Switzerland, a seminar in Mexico and a film show in the Czech Republic between December 9 and 12 to mark the 18th anniversary of General Secretary Kim Jong Il's assumption of the supreme commandership of the Korean People's Army and the 92nd birth anniversary of Kim Jong Suk, anti-Japanese heroine.
					 Martin Lotscher, chairman of the Switzerland-Korea Committee, said in his speech that Kim Jong Il inherited and developed the Songun idea founded by President Kim Il Sung and has successfully embodied the Songun politics in all fields. Thanks to the Songun politics pursued by him, today the DPRK has turned into a satellite possessor and a powerful country with strong nuclear deterrent, recognized by the world, the speaker added.
					
					 He said that Kim Jong Suk was a bodyguard who devotedly defended Kim Il Sung and a revolutionary comrade-in-arms most faithful to him, mother of Korea who gave birth to the sun of Juche and a prominent woman revolutionary who devoted her all to the Korean women's emancipation movement, freedom and independence of the country and happiness of the people.
					
					 Ramon Jimenez Lopez, president of the Mexican Committee for the Study of Kimilsungism, said at the seminar that Kim Jong Il defended Korean-style socialism by containing the imperialists' offensive against socialism and the DPRK with the might of Songun, upholding the banner of the Juche idea and Songun.
					
					 He praised Kim Jong Suk as a great revolutionary who performed great exploits for the liberation of Korea, building of a new society and the cause of building the army.
					
					 The participants of the film show watched the Korean film "Fireworks for a Thriving Nation".
					
					 A message of greetings to Kim Jong Il was adopted at the meeting held in Switzerland.

articles.title: Kim Jong Il recibe carta personal de Barack Obama
articles.content:
Kim Jong Il recibe carta personal de Barack Obama
Pyongyang, 18 de diciembre (ATCC) -- El Dirigente Kim Jong Il recibio la carta personal que le mandara el Presidente de los Estados Unidos de America, Barack Obama.
					  La carta fue transmitida el dia 9 al primer vicecanciller coreano Kang Sok Ju por Stephen Bosworth, representante especial de Estados Unidos para la politica sobre la Republica Popular Democratica de Corea, quien realizo una visita a esta.

articles.title: Kim Jong Il expresa condolencias por deceso de Kim Kun Ok
articles.content:
Kim Jong Il expresa condolencias por deceso de Kim Kun Ok
Pyongyang, 18 de diciembre (ATCC) -- El Dirigente Kim Jong Il envio el dia 18 una ofrenda floral ante el feretro del difunto general del Ejercito Popular de Corea Kim Kun Ok, quien trabajaba de guia del Museo Conmemorativo de la Victoria en la Guerra de Liberacion de la Patria, en senal de profundas condolencias por su fallecimiento.
